definition: lasting for a very short time
example: The ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms reminds us to appreciate fleeting moments.

definition: present, appearing, or found everywhere
example: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

definition: dealing with things sensibly and realistically rather than ideally
example: Her pragmatic approach to budgeting helped the company survive the recession.

definition: fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing
example: The lawyer delivered an eloquent closing argument that moved the jury to tears.

definition: having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way
example: The pernicious influence of misinformation eroded public trust in institutions.

definition: clear, logical, and convincing
example: She presented a cogent argument for restructuring the department.

definition: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring
example: The arduous hike through the mountain pass tested even the most experienced climbers.

definition: severe or strict in manner or attitude; having no comforts or luxuries
example: The monastery maintained an austere lifestyle with minimal furnishings.

definition: well-meaning and kindly; generous
example: The benevolent donor funded scholarships for underprivileged students.

definition: given to sudden and unaccountable changes of mood or behavior
example: The capricious weather forced us to pack for every possible condition.

definition: causing harm or damage
example: The deleterious effects of pollution on marine life are well documented.

definition: outstandingly bad; shocking
example: The report revealed egregious violations of safety regulations at the factory.

definition: treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor
example: His facetious remarks during the meeting irritated his colleagues.

definition: fond of company; sociable
example: Her gregarious personality made her the perfect host for large gatherings.

definition: lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal
example: The novel relied on hackneyed plot devices that made it predictable.

definition: challenging or overthrowing traditional beliefs, customs, or values
example: The artist's iconoclastic work defied every convention of the genre.

definition: having, showing, or done with good judgment or sense
example: A judicious use of resources allowed the project to finish under budget.

definition: using very few words
example: His laconic reply of 'possibly' left everyone wondering what he truly meant.

definition: generous or forgiving, especially toward a rival or less powerful person
example: The magnanimous winner congratulated her opponent on a well-fought match.

definition: wicked or criminal
example: The detective uncovered a nefarious scheme to defraud elderly investors.

definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action
example: The obstinate negotiator refused to make any concessions.

definition: excessively concerned with minor details or rules
example: His pedantic insistence on grammar corrections made him unpopular in the writing group.

definition: complaining in a petulant or whining manner
example: The querulous customer demanded to speak with every level of management.

definition: not revealing one's thoughts or feelings readily
example: She remained reticent about her plans until the deal was finalized.

definition: optimistic or positive, especially in a difficult situation
example: Despite the setback, the CEO remained sanguine about the company's future.

definition: reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little
example: The taciturn farmer answered questions with single-word responses.

definition: not able to be maintained or defended against attack or objection
example: The committee's position became untenable once the evidence was released.

definition: having or showing a lack of thought or intelligence; mindless
example: The interview was filled with vacuous responses that revealed no substance.

definition: deliberate and unprovoked; without regard for consequences
example: The wanton destruction of the historic building outraged the community.

definition: having or showing great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause
example: The zealous volunteer spent every weekend cleaning up the local park.

definition: sharp and forthright in manner or speech
example: Her acerbic wit made her the most feared book reviewer in the industry.

definition: hostile and aggressive
example: The belligerent tone of the letter made productive dialogue impossible.

definition: truthful and straightforward; frank
example: The CEO gave a candid assessment of the company's financial difficulties.

definition: modest or shy because of a lack of self-confidence
example: The diffident student rarely spoke up in class despite having brilliant ideas.

definition: open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous
example: The politician's equivocal statement left voters unsure of her actual position.

definition: not having any serious purpose or value
example: The judge dismissed the frivolous lawsuit as a waste of the court's time.

definition: excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters
example: The garrulous taxi driver told us his entire life story during the ride.

definition: arrogantly superior and disdainful
example: The haughty manager refused to listen to suggestions from junior staff.

definition: proceeding in a gradual, subtle way but with harmful effects
example: The insidious spread of the disease went unnoticed for months.

definition: cheerful and friendly
example: The jovial host greeted every guest with a warm handshake and a smile.

definition: deserving praise and commendation
example: Her laudable efforts to improve literacy in the community earned her an award.

definition: lacking interest or excitement; dull
example: He longed for adventure to break up the mundane routine of office life.

definition: just beginning to develop; not yet fully formed
example: The nascent tech startup showed enormous promise despite having only five employees.

definition: obedient or attentive to an excessive degree
example: The obsequious assistant agreed with everything the boss said.

definition: carried out with a minimum of effort or reflection
example: The security guard gave the bag a perfunctory glance before waving us through.

definition: exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
example: His quixotic plan to build a utopian community attracted many dreamers but few investors.

definition: having an obstinately uncooperative attitude
example: The recalcitrant student refused to follow any classroom rules.

definition: superficially plausible but actually wrong
example: His specious argument sounded convincing until you examined the evidence closely.

definition: very weak or slight; insubstantial
example: The connection between the two events seemed tenuous at best.

definition: leaving no doubt; unambiguous
example: The board issued an unequivocal statement condemning the policy.

definition: having or showing a strong desire for revenge
example: The vindictive former employee leaked confidential documents to the press.

definition: playfully quaint or fanciful, especially in an appealing way
example: The whimsical illustrations in the children's book delighted readers of all ages.

definition: having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something
example: She felt ambivalent about the job offer because it required relocating.

definition: so lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring
example: The film's banal dialogue made it difficult to stay engaged.

definition: extremely complex and difficult to follow
example: The convoluted tax code confused even experienced accountants.

definition: essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison
example: The committee struggled to reconcile the disparate viewpoints of its members.

definition: intended for or likely to be understood by only a small number of people
example: The professor's lecture on esoteric philosophical theories lost most of the audience.

definition: attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt
example: He cast a furtive glance over his shoulder before entering the building.

definition: uncalled for; lacking good reason; unwarranted
example: The film's gratuitous violence added nothing to the story.

definition: holding an opinion at odds with what is generally accepted
example: His heretical views on economic policy made him unpopular with the establishment.

definition: unchanging over time or unable to be changed
example: The laws of physics are considered immutable truths of the universe.

definition: characterized by extreme patriotism, especially in the form of aggressive foreign policy
example: The jingoistic rhetoric in the speech alarmed diplomatic observers.

definition: displaying or having a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
example: The languid pace of life in the seaside village was a welcome change.

definition: subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind
example: His mercurial temperament made it hard to know what reaction to expect.

definition: in the form of a cloud or haze; vague or ill-defined
example: The company's nebulous mission statement failed to inspire its employees.

definition: ostentatiously rich and luxurious
example: The opulent ballroom featured crystal chandeliers and marble floors.

definition: seemingly absurd or self-contradictory but potentially true
example: It is paradoxical that the busiest people often find the most time to help others.

definition: involving or limited to basic principles; at an early stage of development
example: The students had only a rudimentary understanding of calculus.

definition: most noticeable or important
example: The report highlighted the most salient findings of the five-year study.

definition: equivalent in seriousness to; virtually the same as
example: Refusing to vote is tantamount to accepting whatever outcome others decide.

definition: having or showing no moral principles; dishonest
example: The unscrupulous landlord ignored building code violations to save money.

definition: using or expressed in more words than are needed
example: The verbose report could have conveyed the same information in half the pages.

definition: conducive to success; favorable
example: The sunny weather on opening day was considered an auspicious sign.

definition: relating to the pleasant aspects of the countryside and country life
example: The bucolic landscape of rolling hills and meadows inspired many painters.

definition: abundant in supply or quantity
example: She took copious notes during every lecture to prepare for the exam.

definition: inclined to lay down principles as incontrovertibly true
example: His dogmatic insistence on a single approach stifled creative problem-solving.

definition: deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources
example: Her eclectic music collection ranged from classical symphonies to punk rock.

definition: having or displaying a passionate intensity
example: The fervent supporters cheered throughout the entire rally.

definition: fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow
example: The politician's glib promises failed to convince skeptical voters.

definition: unfortunate; having bad luck
example: The hapless traveler missed three connecting flights in one day.

definition: assuming power or authority without justification; domineering
example: Her imperious manner alienated colleagues who might otherwise have been allies.

definition: fond of or characterized by joking; humorous
example: His jocular personality made him a favorite at dinner parties.

definition: affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic
example: The heat made everyone feel lethargic and unproductive.

definition: showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise
example: The meticulous craftsman spent hours perfecting each joint in the cabinet.

definition: famous or well known, typically for some bad quality or deed
example: The notorious intersection was the site of dozens of accidents every year.

definition: characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress
example: The ostentatious mansion with its gold fixtures struck visitors as tasteless.

definition: evoking a keen sense of sadness or regret
example: The poignant documentary about displaced families moved audiences to tears.

definition: characterized by bitterness or resentment
example: The rancorous divorce proceedings dragged on for over two years.

definition: diligent, thorough, and extremely attentive to details
example: The scrupulous auditor uncovered discrepancies that others had missed.

definition: lacking originality or freshness; dull on account of overuse
example: The graduation speech was filled with trite advice about following your dreams.

definition: designed to be useful or practical rather than attractive
example: The utilitarian design of the office prioritized efficiency over aesthetics.

definition: wanting or devouring great quantities; having a very eager approach
example: She was a voracious reader who finished several books each week.

definition: without a clearly defined shape or form
example: The amorphous blob of clay slowly took shape under the sculptor's hands.

definition: abrupt or offhand in speech or manner
example: The doctor's brusque bedside manner made patients uncomfortable.

definition: wary and unwilling to take risks
example: The circumspect investor carefully researched every opportunity before committing funds.

definition: not candid or sincere, typically by pretending to know less than one does
example: His disingenuous claim of ignorance fooled no one on the committee.

definition: having or showing great knowledge or learning
example: The erudite professor could discuss topics ranging from quantum physics to Renaissance art.

definition: very attentive to and concerned about accuracy and detail
example: The fastidious editor caught errors that three previous reviewers had missed.

definition: relevant to a subject under consideration
example: The lawyer objected, arguing that the testimony was not germane to the case.

definition: ruling or dominant in a political or social context
example: The hegemonic influence of the corporation extended across multiple industries.

definition: tending to obstruct or harm; hostile
example: The harsh regulations were inimical to small business growth.

definition: clear and transparent; easily understood
example: The limpid prose of her writing made complex ideas accessible to all readers.

definition: sullen and ill-tempered
example: He grew morose after receiving the rejection letter from his top-choice school.

definition: feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed
example: She gave a nonchalant shrug when asked about her impressive test scores.

definition: acceptable or satisfactory; pleasant to taste
example: The committee reworded the proposal to make it more palatable to skeptics.

definition: little known; abstruse
example: The recondite details of the ancient treaty interested only a few historians.

definition: calm, dependable, and showing little emotion or animation
example: The stolid detective remained unfazed by the suspect's outbursts.

definition: eager or quick to argue or fight; aggressively defiant
example: The truculent teenager challenged every rule his parents tried to enforce.

definition: filled with bitter criticism or malice
example: The vitriolic review of the restaurant went viral on social media.

definition: angry and bitter in tone or manner
example: The acrimonious debate between the candidates turned off many voters.

definition: kept secret or done secretively
example: The journalists uncovered a clandestine network of offshore bank accounts.

definition: intended to teach, particularly in having moral instruction as an ulterior motive
example: The novel's didactic tone made it feel more like a lecture than a story.

definition: based on observation or experience rather than theory or pure logic
example: The researchers gathered empirical data to support their hypothesis.

definition: easily irritated; quarrelsome
example: The fractious committee could not agree on even the simplest procedural matters.

definition: complete and airtight; insulated from outside influences
example: The hermetic seal on the container kept the contents fresh for months.

definition: peculiar or individual; relating to idiosyncrasy
example: The chef's idiosyncratic cooking style combined French technique with Korean flavors.

definition: too great or extreme to be expressed or described in words
example: The ineffable beauty of the aurora borealis left the travelers speechless.

definition: looking or sounding sad and dismal
example: The lugubrious music at the memorial set a somber tone for the ceremony.

definition: easily influenced; pliable
example: Young minds are especially malleable, which is why early education matters so much.

definition: experiencing a sentimental longing for the past
example: The old photographs made her feel nostalgic for her childhood summers.

definition: involving an amount of effort and difficulty that is oppressively burdensome
example: The onerous regulations made it nearly impossible for new businesses to open.

definition: recklessly extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources
example: The profligate spending of the previous administration left the treasury empty.

definition: grimly mocking or cynical
example: His sardonic smile suggested he knew more than he was letting on.

definition: lasting only for a short time; impermanent
example: The transient nature of fame is a recurring theme in celebrity culture.

definition: excessively or ingratiatingly flattering; oily
example: The unctuous salesman complimented everything about us in an effort to close the deal.

definition: attractively lively and animated
example: Her vivacious personality lit up every room she entered.

definition: deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected
example: The anomalous test results prompted the scientists to repeat the experiment.

definition: feeling or expressing remorse at having done wrong
example: The contrite employee wrote a sincere apology to the client.

definition: deceitful; double-dealing
example: The duplicitous advisor was secretly working for both sides of the negotiation.

definition: irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with
example: The editor removed extraneous details that slowed the pace of the narrative.

definition: direct and outspoken; straightforward and honest
example: We appreciated her forthright assessment of the project's weaknesses.

definition: unable to be affected by; resistant to
example: She seemed impervious to criticism, maintaining her confidence no matter what.

definition: inborn; natural
example: Her innate talent for music was evident from the time she was a toddler.

definition: tending to talk a great deal; talkative
example: The loquacious professor often ran over the allotted class time.

definition: lacking imagination, foresight, or intellectual insight
example: The company's myopic focus on quarterly profits undermined its long-term strategy.

definition: having a limited or narrow outlook or scope
example: His parochial view of the world prevented him from appreciating other cultures.

definition: having the style or diction of prose; lacking poetic beauty; commonplace
example: The prosaic reality of daily life was far removed from his romantic fantasies.

definition: characterized by or showing interest or concern
example: The solicitous nurse checked on her patients every thirty minutes.

definition: characterized by strong and turbulent or conflicting emotion
example: Their tempestuous relationship was marked by dramatic arguments and reconciliations.

definition: showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect
example: The insolent reply to the teacher resulted in an immediate trip to the principal.

definition: having a great deal of money; wealthy
example: The affluent neighborhood was known for its manicured lawns and luxury vehicles.

definition: gentle and kindly; not harmful in effect
example: Fortunately, the biopsy showed the tumor was benign.

definition: evoking interest, attention, or admiration in a powerfully irresistible way
example: The documentary presented a compelling case for criminal justice reform.

definition: excessively harsh and severe
example: The draconian new attendance policy penalized employees for any absence.

definition: vivacious and enthusiastic
example: Her effervescent personality made even mundane meetings enjoyable.

definition: producing much fruit or foliage or many offspring; present in large quantities
example: The prolific author published three novels in a single year.

definition: not being what it purports to be; false or fake
example: The spurious claims in the advertisement led to a lawsuit.

definition: understood or implied without being stated
example: There was a tacit agreement among the neighbors to keep noise levels down after ten.

definition: relating to deep inward feelings rather than to the intellect
example: The audience had a visceral reaction to the graphic scenes in the film.

definition: departing from an accepted standard
example: The aberrant behavior of the test subjects puzzled the researchers.

definition: sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way
example: Her caustic remarks about the proposal embarrassed its author in front of the team.

definition: tending to weaken or hinder
example: The debilitating illness forced the athlete to withdraw from competition.

definition: unreasonably high in price or amount
example: The exorbitant cost of the repairs exceeded the value of the car itself.

definition: innocent and unsuspecting; candid
example: Her ingenuous questions revealed that she had no knowledge of the company's troubles.

definition: tending or inclined to engage in lawsuits
example: The litigious company had filed suits against nearly all of its competitors.

definition: existing in name only; very small or far below the real value
example: They charged only a nominal fee to cover basic administrative costs.

definition: expressing contempt or disapproval
example: The term was used in a pejorative sense to demean the opposition.

definition: unnecessary, especially through being more than enough
example: The editor cut several superfluous paragraphs that added nothing to the argument.

definition: offering nothing that is stimulating or challenging
example: The vapid conversation at the party drove her to leave early.

definition: not harmful or offensive
example: What seemed like an innocuous comment sparked a heated debate.

definition: having or showing knowledge of events before they take place
example: Her prescient investment in renewable energy paid off handsomely a decade later.

definition: continuing without pause or interruption
example: The incessant rain forced the cancellation of the outdoor festival.

definition: having or showing an ability to accurately assess situations and turn them to one's advantage
example: The astute investor recognized the market shift before anyone else.

definition: open and responsive to suggestion; easily persuaded
example: The team was amenable to changing the deadline once they understood the reasoning.

definition: showing or feeling a strong aversion
example: She was antipathetic to any suggestion that involved public speaking.

definition: corresponding in size or degree; in proportion
example: The salary offered was commensurate with her level of experience.

definition: extremely beautiful or pleasant; delicious
example: The chef prepared a delectable five-course meal for the anniversary dinner.

definition: well chosen or suited to the circumstances; pleasing and fortunate
example: The felicitous phrasing of the toast brought smiles to everyone at the table.

definition: not able to be corrected, improved, or reformed
example: The incorrigible optimist found a silver lining in every setback.

definition: wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy
example: The indolent cat spent the entire afternoon napping in a patch of sunlight.

definition: fearless; adventurous
example: The intrepid explorer ventured deep into uncharted territory.

definition: having or showing a tendency to be easily angered
example: The irascible coach was known for his sideline tirades.

definition: sweet or musical; pleasant to hear
example: The singer's mellifluous voice captivated the entire audience.

definition: translucently clear; easily understood
example: The pellucid waters of the lagoon revealed every detail of the reef below.

definition: holding firmly to an opinion or a course of action
example: The pertinacious negotiator refused to back down until a fair deal was reached.

definition: strongly reminiscent or suggestive of; fragrant
example: The kitchen was redolent of freshly baked bread and cinnamon.

definition: tending to induce drowsiness or sleep
example: The soporific lecture on tax regulations put half the audience to sleep.

definition: loud and harsh; presenting a point of view in an excessively forceful way
example: The strident demands of the protesters could be heard blocks away.

definition: kept secret, especially because it would not be approved of
example: She took a surreptitious glance at her phone during the meeting.

definition: vigorous or incisive in expression or style
example: The columnist was known for her trenchant commentary on political affairs.

definition: accorded a great deal of respect, especially because of age, wisdom, or character
example: The venerable institution celebrated its two hundredth anniversary.

definition: insisting on immediate attention or obedience in a brusquely imperious way
example: The manager issued a peremptory order to stop all work on the project.

definition: indicating a good chance of success; favorable
example: The clear skies were propitious for the outdoor wedding ceremony.

definition: impressive and attractive in appearance
example: The bride looked resplendent in her silk gown on the wedding day.

definition: showing dedication and diligence
example: The sedulous researcher spent years compiling data for the groundbreaking study.

definition: cheerful and full of energy
example: The ebullient crowd erupted in cheers when the final goal was scored.

definition: showing great care and perseverance
example: The assiduous student never missed a single homework assignment in four years.

definition: friendly, lively, and enjoyable in atmosphere
example: The convivial atmosphere at the neighborhood block party brought everyone together.

definition: deserving blame for a wrong or error
example: The investigation determined that both parties were equally culpable for the accident.

definition: spoken or done without preparation
example: Her extemporaneous remarks at the ceremony were more moving than any prepared speech could have been.

definition: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame
example: The team suffered an ignominious defeat, losing by the worst margin in franchise history.

definition: unwilling or refusing to change one's views or to agree about something
example: The intransigent union leaders refused to accept any reduction in benefits.

definition: sexually immoral; promiscuous and unprincipled
example: The licentious behavior at the party shocked the more conservative guests.

definition: using high-flown or bombastic language
example: The magniloquent speech was full of grand promises but short on practical details.

definition: stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or course of action
example: The obdurate CEO pressed forward with the strategy despite unanimous opposition from the board.

definition: extremely poor; unwilling to spend money
example: The penurious landlord refused to make even the most basic repairs to the property.

definition: showing great attention to detail or correct behavior
example: The punctilious host ensured every place setting was perfectly arranged.

definition: having or showing keen mental discernment and good judgment
example: The sagacious advisor warned against the risky investment months before the market crashed.

definition: behaving or done in an obsequious way to gain advantage
example: The sycophantic praise from the staff only inflated the director's already oversized ego.

definition: swollen or congested; tediously pompous or bombastic in language
example: The turgid prose of the academic paper made it nearly unreadable for a general audience.

definition: showing or motivated by susceptibility to bribery; corrupt
example: The venal official accepted payments in exchange for favorable regulatory decisions.

definition: pale and giving the impression of illness or exhaustion
example: The wan expression on her face revealed that she had not slept in days.

definition: childishly silly and trivial
example: The puerile humor of the sitcom appealed to teenagers but annoyed adult viewers.

definition: exhibiting different colors or diverse elements
example: The variegated leaves of the plant displayed shades of green, yellow, and red.

definition: persisting tirelessly; never showing signs of weariness
example: The indefatigable campaigner knocked on doors in every neighborhood.

definition: deceitful and untrustworthy
example: The perfidious ally secretly provided intelligence to the enemy.

definition: seeming reasonable or probable
example: The detective found the suspect's alibi to be plausible but still worth investigating.

definition: involving ignoble actions and motives; morally degrading
example: The sordid details of the corruption scandal dominated the news for weeks.

definition: relating to or along a tangent; only slightly relevant
example: The speaker's tangential remarks about his vacation confused the audience.

definition: a person who acts obsequiously toward someone important to gain advantage
example: The CEO surrounded himself with sycophants who never challenged his decisions.

definition: something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected
example: The warm weather in January was an anomaly that puzzled meteorologists.

definition: concise and exact use of words in writing or speech
example: The brevity of his resignation letter surprised everyone at the company.

definition: a person or thing that precipitates an event or change
example: The viral video served as a catalyst for widespread social reform.

definition: a division or contrast between two things that are represented as being opposed
example: The dichotomy between wealth and poverty in the city was starkly visible.

definition: a person or thing that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand
example: The artist remained an enigma, granting no interviews and making no public appearances.

definition: a mistaken belief based on unsound argument
example: The idea that correlation implies causation is a common logical fallacy.

definition: a person or thing that announces or signals the approach of another
example: The first robin of spring is often considered a harbinger of warmer days.

definition: the force or energy with which a body moves; something that makes a process happen
example: The scandal provided the impetus for sweeping regulatory reform.

definition: the fact of two things being seen or placed close together with contrasting effect
example: The juxtaposition of the modern skyscraper against the ancient temple was striking.

definition: a lack of energy and enthusiasm
example: A wave of lethargy swept over the office during the hot afternoon.

definition: a wrong or inaccurate name or designation
example: Calling it a 'jellyfish' is a misnomer since it is not actually a fish.

definition: a subtle difference in or shade of meaning, expression, or sound
example: The translator struggled to capture every nuance of the original poem.

definition: a typical example or pattern of something; a model
example: The discovery represented a paradigm shift in our understanding of genetics.

definition: the most perfect or typical example of a quality or class
example: The small Italian cafe was the quintessence of charm and hospitality.

definition: the art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing; language designed to persuade
example: The senator's soaring rhetoric inspired a generation of young activists.

definition: a mark of disgrace associated with a particular circumstance, quality, or person
example: The stigma surrounding mental health issues prevents many people from seeking help.

definition: a feeling of fear or agitation about something that may happen
example: She approached the podium with trepidation, having never spoken to such a large audience.

definition: conformity to facts; accuracy; habitual truthfulness
example: The journalist's veracity was never questioned throughout her long career.

definition: the ability to make good judgments and quick decisions
example: Her business acumen helped the startup grow into a multinational corporation.

definition: a deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion
example: His antipathy toward bureaucracy drove him to start his own company.

definition: a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
example: The cacophony of car horns and construction drills made conversation impossible.

definition: a political leader who seeks support by appealing to the desires and prejudices of ordinary people
example: The demagogue whipped up fears about immigration to gain political support.

definition: a person or thing that is a perfect example of a particular quality or type
example: She is the epitome of grace under pressure.

definition: leadership or dominance, especially by one country or social group over others
example: The nation's economic hegemony allowed it to influence global trade policies.

definition: a mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual
example: One of his many idiosyncrasies was arranging his books by color rather than author.

definition: a wealthy and influential person, especially in business or industry
example: The media magnate owned newspapers, television stations, and streaming platforms.

definition: the rejection of all religious and moral principles, often in the belief that life is meaningless
example: The character's descent into nihilism reflected the novel's bleak worldview.

definition: a solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases
example: Technology is often touted as a panacea for society's problems, but it has limitations.

definition: a state of perplexity or uncertainty over what to do in a difficult situation
example: The ethical quandary forced the doctor to weigh patient confidentiality against public safety.

definition: an accusation in response to one from someone else
example: The meeting devolved into mutual recriminations rather than productive discussion.

definition: a split or division between strongly opposed sections or parties
example: The schism within the organization threatened to destroy decades of progress.

definition: depravity; wickedness
example: The official was removed from office for moral turpitude.

definition: offense or annoyance
example: She took umbrage at the suggestion that her work was anything less than excellent.

definition: a change of circumstances or fortune, typically one that is unwelcome
example: The vicissitudes of the stock market taught him the importance of diversification.

definition: the action or process of combining or uniting
example: The amalgamation of the two companies created the largest retailer in the region.

definition: a scarcity or lack of something
example: The dearth of affordable housing has become a crisis in major cities.

definition: the state or feeling of being actively opposed or hostile
example: Years of enmity between the two families finally ended with a reconciliation.

definition: courage in pain or adversity
example: The survivors showed remarkable fortitude in rebuilding their community after the disaster.

definition: excessive pride or self-confidence; arrogance
example: The CEO's hubris led him to ignore warnings that ultimately caused the company's downfall.

definition: immoral or grossly unfair behavior
example: The documentary exposed the iniquity of the system that exploited vulnerable workers.

definition: wrongdoing, especially by a public official
example: The investigation uncovered widespread malfeasance within the city government.

definition: lack of experience, wisdom, or judgment; innocence
example: His naivete about office politics made him easy prey for more cunning colleagues.

definition: the action of making something obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
example: The politician's response was pure obfuscation, designed to avoid answering the question.

definition: extreme unwillingness to spend money or use resources
example: The company's parsimony with employee benefits led to high turnover rates.

definition: bitterness or resentfulness, especially when long-standing
example: Despite the rancor of the campaign, the two candidates shook hands after the election.

definition: the quality of being sagacious; having good judgment
example: The elder's sagacity was sought by everyone in the village during times of crisis.

definition: the quality of being very determined; persistence
example: Her tenacity in pursuing the investigation eventually led to a breakthrough.

definition: the appearance of being true or real
example: The author's attention to historical detail gave the novel an impressive verisimilitude.

definition: a person who is fanatical and uncompromising in pursuit of their ideals
example: The political zealot refused to consider any viewpoint that differed from his own.

definition: extreme greed for wealth or material gain
example: The banker's avarice ultimately led to his conviction for fraud.

definition: a person falsely claiming to have special knowledge or skill; a fraud
example: The self-proclaimed healer was exposed as a charlatan who exploited desperate patients.

definition: a ruler who holds absolute power, typically one who exercises it in a cruel way
example: The despot silenced all opposition through intimidation and censorship.

definition: a mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered too harsh or blunt
example: 'Downsizing' is a common euphemism for laying off employees.

definition: a complete failure, especially a ludicrous or humiliating one
example: The product launch turned into a fiasco when the software crashed during the live demo.

definition: a pompous or extravagant style of language
example: The politician's grandiloquence masked a lack of substantive policy proposals.

definition: the practice of claiming to have moral standards to which one's own behavior does not conform
example: Voters grew tired of the hypocrisy of officials who preached fiscal discipline while overspending.

definition: a situation in which no progress is possible, especially because of disagreement
example: The negotiations reached an impasse when neither side would compromise on the key issue.

definition: a huge, powerful, and overwhelming force or institution
example: The tech company grew into a juggernaut that dominated the entire industry.

definition: a complicated irregular network of passages or paths; a maze
example: The old city's streets formed a labyrinth that confused even longtime residents.

definition: a general feeling of discomfort, illness, or uneasiness
example: A sense of malaise settled over the team after the third consecutive quarterly loss.

definition: the inescapable agent of someone's downfall; a long-standing rival
example: Overconfidence proved to be his nemesis in the championship match.

definition: a small group of people having control of a country or organization
example: Critics argued that the nation had become an oligarchy controlled by a handful of billionaires.

definition: a general rule intended to regulate behavior or thought
example: The precept of treating others as you wish to be treated guides many ethical systems.

definition: a stock of skills or types of behavior that a person habitually uses
example: The experienced manager had a wide repertoire of conflict resolution techniques.

definition: an act of speaking one's thoughts aloud when by oneself, especially in a play
example: Hamlet's 'To be or not to be' soliloquy is one of the most famous passages in English literature.

definition: a false, absurd, or distorted representation of something
example: The trial was widely condemned as a travesty of justice.

definition: a group of people leading the way in new developments or ideas
example: The university's research lab has been at the vanguard of artificial intelligence.

definition: an event or period marking a turning point
example: The landmark ruling was a watershed moment in the history of civil rights.

definition: a natural liking for and understanding of someone or something
example: She felt an immediate affinity with her new colleagues.

definition: the middle class, typically with reference to its perceived materialistic values
example: The revolution was driven by resentment of the wealthy bourgeoisie.

definition: a confusing and difficult problem or question
example: The budget deficit presented a conundrum that no simple solution could resolve.

definition: a sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco
example: The company's expansion into foreign markets turned into a costly debacle.

definition: the ability to produce a desired or intended result
example: The clinical trial demonstrated the efficacy of the new treatment.

definition: intense and passionate feeling
example: The crowd sang the national anthem with patriotic fervor.

definition: an unintentional act or remark causing embarrassment
example: The diplomat's gaffe at the state dinner created an international incident.

definition: a pause or gap in a sequence, series, or process
example: After a two-year hiatus, the band announced a reunion tour.

definition: an allusive or oblique remark or hint, typically a suggestive or disparaging one
example: The article was filled with innuendo that damaged the candidate's reputation.

definition: a situation or state of confused movement or violent turmoil
example: The political maelstrom following the scandal consumed the entire administration.

definition: the devising or choosing of names for things, especially in a science
example: The nomenclature of organic chemistry follows a systematic set of rules.

definition: the method and practice of teaching
example: Modern pedagogy emphasizes critical thinking over rote memorization.

definition: the minimum number of members of an assembly needed to conduct business
example: Without a quorum present, the board could not vote on the proposed changes.

definition: deceit used to achieve one's goal
example: The spy relied on subterfuge to gain access to the classified documents.

definition: a person or thing that is the direct opposite of someone or something else
example: His casual leadership style was the antithesis of his predecessor's rigid approach.

definition: a huge or monstrous creature; something enormous
example: The retail behemoth operated thousands of stores across the globe.

definition: the quality of being clear, logical, and convincing
example: The cogency of her argument persuaded even the most skeptical members of the panel.

definition: a great difference
example: The disparity in wealth between the two neighborhoods was impossible to ignore.

definition: the characteristic spirit of a culture, era, or community
example: The company's ethos of innovation attracted top talent from around the world.

definition: material used as a basis for discussion or argument
example: The celebrity's arrest provided endless fodder for tabloid journalists.

definition: an act or remark intended to gain an advantage
example: The opening gambit in the negotiation was a surprisingly generous offer.

definition: the quality or state of being all the same or all of the same kind
example: Critics of the program pointed to the homogeneity of its participants as a weakness.

definition: the state of being unwilling or unable to believe something
example: The audience reacted with incredulity when the magician appeared to vanish entirely.

definition: the quality of having a ready insight into things; shrewdness
example: Her perspicacity in reading market trends made her the firm's most successful analyst.

definition: a sharing of characteristics or origins; a feeling of being close or connected
example: She felt a strong kinship with other first-generation college students.

definition: a passionate expression of grief or sorrow
example: The poem was a lament for the loss of childhood innocence.

definition: a short, pithy statement expressing a general truth or rule of conduct
example: He lived by the maxim that actions speak louder than words.

definition: the practice of favoring relatives or friends, especially by giving them jobs
example: Allegations of nepotism arose when the mayor appointed his nephew to a senior position.

definition: harsh criticism or censure; public disgrace
example: The company faced widespread opprobrium after the environmental disaster.

definition: a remark or statement that has been used too often to be interesting or thoughtful
example: The speech was full of platitudes about hard work and perseverance but offered no real insight.

definition: the practice of exchanging things with others for mutual benefit
example: International trade agreements are built on the principle of reciprocity.

definition: the use of clever but false arguments, especially with the intention of deceiving
example: The defense attorney's sophistry nearly convinced the jury to acquit.

definition: a long, angry speech of criticism or accusation
example: The coach launched into a tirade about the team's lack of effort.

definition: the act of taking a position of power or importance illegally or by force
example: The general's usurpation of the presidency triggered international condemnation.

definition: the faculty or power of using one's will
example: She left the company of her own volition, not because she was pressured to resign.

definition: dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries
example: The rise in xenophobia led to several hate crimes in the community.

definition: a feeling of intense longing for something
example: The immigrant's yearning for home was palpable in every letter she wrote.

definition: the defining spirit or mood of a particular period of history
example: The film perfectly captured the zeitgeist of the anxious post-war era.

definition: a preference or special liking for something
example: Her predilection for mystery novels was evident from her overflowing bookshelf.

definition: a tendency to choose or do something regularly; an inclination or predisposition
example: His proclivity for procrastination caused him to miss several deadlines.

definition: a forceful and bitter verbal attack against someone or something
example: The senator delivered a lengthy diatribe against the proposed legislation.

definition: a model of excellence or perfection of a kind
example: She was considered a paragon of virtue in the community.

definition: an inclination or natural tendency to behave in a particular way
example: The child showed a propensity for art from a very young age.

definition: a disposition to fight or be combative
example: The boxer's pugnacity outside the ring often landed him in trouble.

definition: approval or praise
example: The new policy received widespread approbation from industry experts.

definition: a feeling of guilt or moral scruple that prevents or follows wrongdoing
example: He felt no compunction about cutting corners to finish the project on time.

definition: a situation in which two or more things come together or occur at the same time
example: The city's success was due to a confluence of talented people, strong institutions, and favorable geography.

definition: an urgent need or demand
example: The exigencies of war forced the government to ration basic supplies.

definition: the quality of being generous, forgiving, or noble
example: His magnanimity in defeat earned him the respect of his competitors.

definition: public shame or disgrace
example: The scandal brought ignominy upon the entire organization.

definition: something or someone that one vehemently dislikes
example: Censorship is anathema to those who believe in free expression.

definition: a stronghold or fortified area; an institution strongly maintaining particular principles
example: The university remained a bastion of academic freedom during turbulent times.

definition: the use of trickery to achieve a political, financial, or legal purpose
example: The company engaged in financial chicanery to inflate its reported earnings.

definition: deceitfulness; double-dealing
example: The spy's duplicity was only revealed after decades of service.

definition: mental calmness, composure, and evenness of temper, especially in a difficult situation
example: She faced the crisis with remarkable equanimity, calming everyone around her.

definition: ornamental work of fine wire; intricate and delicate detail
example: The architect added filigree to the balcony railings that gave the building its distinctive character.

definition: the pursuit of pleasure; the ethical theory that pleasure is the highest good
example: The character's unrestrained hedonism eventually led to his downfall.

definition: a person who attacks or criticizes cherished beliefs or institutions
example: The young iconoclast challenged every assumption the industry held dear.

definition: generosity in bestowing money or gifts upon others
example: The billionaire's largesse funded hospitals, schools, and libraries across the country.

definition: a plot or scheme, especially one involving deceit
example: The detective unraveled the machinations of the criminal network.

definition: a strong or habitual liking for something or tendency to do something
example: His penchant for expensive suits was well known among his colleagues.

definition: a difficult, precarious, or entrapping situation
example: The project became a quagmire of missed deadlines and budget overruns.

definition: a person who tells anecdotes in a skillful and amusing way
example: The famous raconteur kept the dinner guests enthralled with one story after another.

definition: excessive flattery or obsequious behavior motivated by self-interest
example: The culture of sycophancy around the CEO prevented honest feedback from reaching him.

definition: the saying of the same thing twice in different words; needless repetition of an idea
example: Saying 'free gift' is a common tautology since all gifts are free by definition.

definition: a brief evocative description, account, or episode
example: The book was composed of charming vignettes from the author's childhood in rural France.

definition: lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern
example: Voter apathy contributed to the lowest turnout in decades.

definition: the place of origin or earliest known history of something
example: The art dealer meticulously documented the provenance of every painting in the gallery.

definition: to repeal or do away with a law, right, or formal agreement
example: The new administration sought to abrogate the trade agreement signed by its predecessor.

definition: to support or strengthen; to prop up
example: The positive earnings report helped bolster investor confidence.

definition: to reprimand someone severely
example: The editorial castigated the government for its slow response to the crisis.

definition: to make someone weak and infirm
example: The chronic illness debilitated him to the point where he could no longer work.

definition: to make something clear; explain
example: The professor used diagrams to elucidate the complex biological process.

definition: to invent or concoct something, typically with deceitful intent
example: The witness was later found to have fabricated key details of her testimony.

definition: to shock or excite someone into taking action
example: The tragedy galvanized the community into demanding stricter safety regulations.

definition: to hinder or impede the movement or progress of
example: The blizzard hampered rescue efforts in the remote mountain villages.

definition: to dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of
example: The defense attorney attempted to impugn the credibility of the prosecution's witness.

definition: to place close together or side by side for comparison or contrast
example: The filmmaker juxtaposed scenes of luxury with images of poverty.

definition: to light or set on fire; to arouse or inspire
example: The teacher's enthusiasm kindled a love of science in her students.

definition: to publicly criticize someone or something by using ridicule or sarcasm
example: The satirical show regularly lampooned politicians from both parties.

definition: to make less severe, serious, or painful
example: Planting trees along the highway helped mitigate the noise for nearby residents.

definition: to nullify or make ineffective
example: The new evidence negated the prosecution's entire argument.

definition: to render obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
example: Complex jargon can obfuscate the true meaning of a contract.

definition: to make someone less angry or hostile
example: The company offered refunds to placate the dissatisfied customers.

definition: to put an end to; suppress
example: The manager's calm reassurance helped quell the team's anxieties about the merger.

definition: to revoke, cancel, or repeal a law, order, or agreement
example: The university decided to rescind the student's admission after discovering falsified records.

definition: to supersede and replace
example: Digital streaming has supplanted physical media as the primary way people consume music.

definition: to shorten by cutting off the top or end
example: The editor truncated the article to fit within the magazine's word limit.

definition: to emphasize or draw attention to
example: The audit results underscore the need for better financial oversight.

definition: to clear someone of blame or suspicion; to show to be right
example: The DNA evidence vindicated the man who had been wrongfully imprisoned for twenty years.

definition: to become unsteady or begin to falter
example: Her resolve never wavered despite months of setbacks and criticism.

definition: to make a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling worse
example: The drought exacerbated existing food shortages in the region.

definition: to make something bad or unsatisfactory better
example: The new policies were designed to ameliorate working conditions in factories.

definition: to charm or enchant someone, sometimes in a deceptive way
example: The con artist beguiled investors with promises of extraordinary returns.

definition: to cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender
example: After a week-long siege, the defenders finally capitulated.

definition: to criticize unfairly; disparage
example: He refused to denigrate his competitors, preferring to let his work speak for itself.

definition: to cause someone to feel drained of energy or vitality
example: The oppressive heat enervated everyone who tried to work outdoors.

definition: to prevent or obstruct by taking advance action
example: The company issued a public apology to forestall a potential boycott.

definition: to gather or collect something, especially information or approval
example: The documentary garnered widespread critical acclaim and several awards.

definition: to create difficulties for someone or something, resulting in delay
example: Bureaucratic red tape continues to hinder economic development in the region.

definition: to instill an attitude, idea, or habit by persistent instruction
example: The program aims to inculcate a sense of civic responsibility in young people.

definition: to put someone or something into a situation in which there is a danger of loss or harm
example: Leaking the information would jeopardize the entire investigation.

definition: to lose or lack vitality; grow weak or feeble
example: The bill languished in committee for months before finally being brought to a vote.

definition: to appease the anger or anxiety of someone
example: The apology did little to mollify the outraged customers.

definition: to make legally void; invalidate
example: The court's ruling nullified the contract, releasing both parties from their obligations.

definition: to move or swing back and forth at a regular speed; to waver between extremes
example: Public opinion on the issue continued to oscillate throughout the election cycle.

definition: to make something continue indefinitely
example: The outdated curriculum perpetuated misconceptions about historical events.

definition: to voluntarily cease to keep or claim; give up
example: The CEO agreed to relinquish control of the company to the new leadership team.

definition: to examine or inspect closely and thoroughly
example: The auditor scrutinized every line of the financial report for irregularities.

definition: to be or go beyond the range or limits of
example: Great art has the power to transcend cultural and linguistic barriers.

definition: to take a position of power or importance illegally or by force
example: The general attempted to usurp the president's authority during the crisis.

definition: to alternate or waver between different opinions or actions
example: She vacillated between accepting the offer and waiting for a better one.

definition: to decrease gradually in power, size, or intensity
example: Public interest in the scandal began to wane after several weeks.

definition: to become less intense or widespread
example: The storm showed no signs of abating as the night wore on.

definition: to fail to give a true notion or impression of something
example: Her calm expression belied the anxiety she felt inside.

definition: to come together and form one mass or whole
example: Several small activist groups coalesced into a powerful political movement.

definition: to regard or represent as being of little worth
example: She refused to disparage the efforts of her teammates, even after the loss.

definition: to adopt or support a cause, belief, or way of life
example: The candidate espoused policies that appealed to both progressive and moderate voters.

definition: to rise and fall irregularly in number or amount
example: Gas prices fluctuated dramatically throughout the summer months.

definition: to engage in a close fight or struggle without weapons; to struggle with a difficulty
example: Policymakers continue to grapple with the challenge of providing affordable healthcare.

definition: to sharpen or refine something over time
example: She spent years honing her craft before publishing her first novel.

definition: to delay or prevent by obstructing
example: Dense fog impeded visibility and caused several highway accidents.

definition: to throw or drop something from an aircraft or ship; to abandon or discard
example: The company decided to jettison its underperforming product line.

definition: to praise highly, especially in a public context
example: Critics lauded the director's bold vision and innovative storytelling techniques.

definition: to speak about someone in a spitefully critical manner
example: The tabloids frequently maligned the actor with unsubstantiated rumors.

definition: to care for and encourage the growth or development of
example: The mentorship program was designed to nurture young entrepreneurs.

definition: to exclude someone from a society or group
example: The community ostracized the family after the scandal became public.

definition: to increase rapidly in numbers; multiply
example: Social media platforms have proliferated over the past decade.

definition: to express sharp disapproval or criticism of someone
example: The judge rebuked the attorney for her unprofessional conduct in the courtroom.

definition: to prevent or hinder the progress of
example: A lack of funding stymied the research team's efforts to develop a prototype.

definition: to travel across or through
example: The hikers traversed the entire length of the national park in two weeks.

definition: to erode the base or foundation of; to lessen the effectiveness of
example: Constant criticism can undermine a child's self-confidence.

definition: to regard with great respect; revere
example: The community venerated the elderly teacher who had taught three generations.

definition: to accept something reluctantly but without protest
example: After much debate, she acquiesced to the board's decision to postpone the project.

definition: to scold or criticize someone angrily
example: The coach berated the player for making such a careless mistake.

definition: to find a way around an obstacle or to overcome a problem
example: The company found a legal way to circumvent the new regulations.

definition: to spread information, knowledge, or ideas widely
example: The organization worked to disseminate accurate health information to rural communities.

definition: to absolve someone from blame for a fault or wrongdoing
example: New evidence exonerated the suspect, leading to his immediate release.

definition: to instigate or stir up an undesirable sentiment or course of action
example: Agents provocateurs attempted to foment unrest among the workers.

definition: to make suffering, deficiency, or a problem less severe
example: The new medication helped alleviate the patient's chronic pain.

definition: to lecture someone at length in an aggressive and critical manner
example: The activist harangued passersby about the importance of recycling.

definition: to overwhelm someone with things or people to be dealt with
example: Customer service was inundated with calls after the product recall was announced.

definition: to prevent from happening; make impossible
example: The severe weather precluded any possibility of an outdoor ceremony.

definition: to consign or dismiss to an inferior rank or position
example: The once-popular theory was relegated to a footnote in modern textbooks.

definition: to bring under domination or control, especially by conquest
example: The empire sought to subjugate neighboring territories through military force.

definition: to prevent someone from accomplishing something
example: Quick action by security thwarted the attempted break-in.

definition: to publicly recommend or support
example: The organization advocates for stronger environmental protection laws.

definition: to increase the strength of or justification for; reinforce
example: The new data buttressed the researchers' original hypothesis.

definition: to confirm or give support to a statement, theory, or finding
example: Multiple witnesses corroborated the victim's account of the incident.

definition: to describe or portray something precisely
example: The contract clearly delineated the responsibilities of each party.

definition: to cause or give rise to a feeling, situation, or condition
example: The policy change engendered a sense of optimism among employees.

definition: to struggle or stagger helplessly or clumsily
example: The new manager floundered in her first weeks, unsure of the company's processes.

definition: to make widely known; to put a law or decree into effect
example: The government promulgated new regulations governing data privacy.

definition: to restore friendly relations between; to make compatible
example: The mediator helped reconcile the feuding business partners.

definition: to waste something, especially money or time, in a reckless and foolish manner
example: He squandered his inheritance on lavish parties and poor investments.

definition: to provide evidence to support or prove the truth of
example: The prosecution failed to substantiate its claims with credible evidence.

definition: to renounce or reject something desired or valuable
example: The monks abnegated all worldly possessions upon entering the monastery.

definition: to polish something by rubbing; to enhance or improve
example: The public relations team worked hard to burnish the company's damaged reputation.

definition: to express severe disapproval of someone or something, especially in a formal statement
example: The ethics committee voted to censure the senator for his misconduct.

definition: to raise doubts or objections or show reluctance
example: When asked to work overtime again, she finally demurred, citing her need for personal time.

definition: to say or pronounce clearly; to express a proposition or theory precisely
example: The professor enunciated each point of her thesis with remarkable clarity.

definition: to obstruct progress in a legislative assembly by making long speeches
example: The opposition party threatened to filibuster the bill until their demands were met.

definition: to use gestures, especially dramatic ones, instead of or in addition to speaking
example: The animated speaker gesticulated wildly to emphasize his most important points.

definition: to ask someone pressingly and persistently for or to do something
example: Lobbyists importuned the senator to support the infrastructure bill.

definition: to remove a need or difficulty; to avoid or prevent
example: The new software update obviated the need for the manual workaround.

definition: to express one's opinions in a way considered annoyingly pompous and dogmatic
example: He spent the entire dinner pontificating about the decline of modern cinema.

definition: to think deeply about something
example: She spent the weekend ruminating on the career change she had been considering.

definition: to leave a place that one previously occupied; to give up a position
example: The tenants were given sixty days to vacate the building before demolition.

definition: apparently or purportedly, but perhaps not actually
example: The meeting was ostensibly about budget cuts, but the real agenda was restructuring.

definition: in a way that is understood or implied without being directly stated
example: By not objecting, the board tacitly approved the CEO's controversial decision.

definition: in a way that leaves no doubt; clearly and decisively
example: The spokesperson unequivocally denied the allegations against the company.

definition: in a forceful, passionate, or intense manner
example: The senator vehemently opposed the bill, calling it a threat to civil liberties.

definition: in a deliberate and unprovoked way
example: The vandals wantonly destroyed the public artwork that had taken months to create.

definition: on the basis of random choice or personal whim rather than any reason or system
example: The rules seemed to be enforced arbitrarily, with some people penalized and others not.

definition: in a truthful and straightforward way; frankly
example: She candidly admitted that the project had not gone as planned.

definition: in a way that shows care and conscientiousness in one's work
example: The student diligently reviewed every chapter before the final exam.

definition: in a forceful way; with emphasis
example: The CEO emphatically stated that there would be no layoffs this quarter.

definition: in a very attentive and concerned manner about accuracy and detail
example: She fastidiously checked every line of code before submitting the project.

definition: in a reluctant or resentful manner
example: He grudgingly accepted the compromise after weeks of negotiation.

definition: in a manner lacking any obvious principle of organization
example: Documents were haphazardly stacked on every surface in the cluttered office.

definition: in a way that is not directly expressed; in an absolute and unquestioning way
example: She implicitly trusted her partner's judgment in financial matters.

definition: with good judgment or sense
example: She judiciously allocated the limited funds to maximize their impact.

definition: in a way that deserves praise and commendation
example: The organization laudably committed to transparency in all its financial dealings.

definition: in a way that shows great attention to detail; very thoroughly
example: The restoration team meticulously repaired every detail of the historic painting.

definition: in a casually calm and relaxed manner
example: He nonchalantly mentioned his promotion as if it were no big deal.

definition: in a seemingly absurd or self-contradictory way
example: Paradoxically, the more choices consumers have, the less satisfied they tend to be.

definition: in an admirably purposeful, determined, and unwavering manner
example: She resolutely pursued her goal despite facing obstacle after obstacle.

definition: in a way that attempts to avoid notice or attention; secretively
example: He surreptitiously passed the note to his colleague under the table.

definition: with a firm hold of something; with great persistence
example: The journalist tenaciously pursued the story for over a year before publishing.

definition: in a way that is present, appearing, or found everywhere
example: The brand's logo appeared ubiquitously across the city's billboards and bus stops.

definition: in a way that is experienced through imaginative participation in another person's experience
example: She lived vicariously through her daughter's travels to exotic destinations.

definition: in a cautious manner; watchfully
example: The cat warily approached the unfamiliar object in the middle of the room.

definition: with great energy or enthusiasm in pursuit of a cause or objective
example: The new employee zealously tackled every assignment given to her.

definition: in a shrewd and perceptive manner
example: She astutely recognized the opportunity before her competitors did.

definition: in large amounts; abundantly
example: She wept copiously when she heard the unexpected good news.

definition: in a way that shows hesitation or doubt; with suspicion
example: The auditor looked dubiously at the financial records that seemed too perfect.

definition: in a fluent or persuasive manner
example: The witness eloquently described the events of that fateful evening.

definition: in a way that shows very strong feelings
example: The community fervently hoped the new hospital would be completed on schedule.

definition: in a fluent manner that suggests insincerity or shallowness
example: He glibly explained away the discrepancies in his expense report.

definition: without interruption; constantly
example: The dog barked incessantly until its owner returned home.

definition: in a manner lacking enthusiasm and determination; carelessly lazy
example: The student lackadaisically flipped through the textbook without reading a single page.

definition: in a generous or forgiving manner, especially toward a rival
example: The champion magnanimously praised the skills of the opponent who nearly defeated him.

definition: to a degree that is not worth considering; insignificantly
example: The new process increased costs only negligibly while dramatically improving quality.

definition: in a showy manner designed to impress
example: He ostentatiously displayed his expensive watch at every opportunity.

definition: in a way that shows a lack of effort or care
example: The inspector perfunctorily glanced at the documents and stamped them approved.

definition: in a grimly mocking or cynical manner
example: She sardonically observed that the 'brief' meeting had lasted three hours.

definition: in a way that is weak, insubstantial, or slight
example: The theory was only tenuously supported by the available evidence.

definition: in an eager or enthusiastic manner; with great appetite
example: The child voraciously devoured the stack of comic books in a single afternoon.

definition: with complete sincerity and commitment
example: The team wholeheartedly supported the new initiative from day one.

definition: in a way that shows a perceptive understanding or insight; intensely
example: She was acutely aware of the tension in the room as the vote approached.

definition: in a well-meaning and kindly manner
example: The grandmother smiled benevolently at her grandchildren as they played.

definition: in a clearly visible manner; in a way that attracts notice
example: The building's modern design stood out conspicuously among the historic facades.

definition: in a way that is essentially different or distinct in quality or kind
example: The policy affected different communities disparately, raising concerns about fairness.

definition: in a manner that treats serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor
example: When asked if he enjoyed the twelve-hour meeting, he facetiously replied it was the highlight of his year.

definition: without good reason; unjustifiably; freely
example: The film gratuitously included shocking scenes that added nothing to the plot.

definition: in a way that is impossible to stop or prevent
example: Time moved inexorably forward as the deadline approached.

definition: to a great degree; in large amounts
example: She apologized profusely for the misunderstanding and offered to make things right.

definition: in every case or on every occasion; always
example: The trains invariably arrived late during the winter months.

definition: in a way that is false or fake despite appearing plausible
example: The data was spuriously correlated, leading researchers to draw incorrect conclusions.

definition: in a reserved or uncommunicative manner
example: He taciturnly nodded when asked whether he agreed with the plan.

definition: in a loud and forceful manner
example: The crowd vociferously protested the decision to close the community center.

definition: in a very careful and thorough way
example: The accountant scrupulously reviewed every transaction for signs of irregularity.
